intro: Ophiorrhiza ciliata, commonly known as the hairy mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in tropical and subtropical regions. It has small, ovate leaves with hairy surfaces, and its flowers are typically white or pale yellow, arranged in clusters. The plant produces small, fleshy berries that are dispersed by birds. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its unique ability to derive some of its nutrients from host plants. Ophiorrhiza ciliata is often found in moist, shaded environments and plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat.
